<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>

They will investigate the code fragments you give.

- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_BeginTest:
```c
void UtAssert_BeginTest(const char *SegmentName)
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));
    strncpy(CurrentSegment, SegmentName, sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1);
    CurrentSegment[sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1] = 0;
    TestSegmentCount                           = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(TestSegmentCount, SegmentName);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_BeginTest:

...

UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_TotalCounters   = {0}

void UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(uint32 SegmentNumber, const char *SegmentName)
{
    char ReportBuffer[128];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNumber, SegmentName);
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN, ReportBuffer);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in the provided code. In UtAssert_BeginTest the parameter is declared as const char *SegmentName and is only used for reading (passed to strncpy and to UT_BSP_StartTestSegment). There is no assignment to SegmentName, no pointer arithmetic on it, and no redefinition that would modify the pointer itself. strncpy writes into CurrentSegment (a separate global array), which is allowed (the object referred to by the parameter may be accessed but the pointer variable is not modified). UT_BSP_StartTestSegment also takes a const char * parameter and only reads it (uses it in snprintf), so it does not modify its parameter either. Other statements in the function (memset, assignment to TestSegmentCount, calls to UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock) do not modify any function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
